conclusion: The problem involves a truck and a bus traveling in the same lane on a highway, with the bus in front and the truck behind. Both vehicles apply their brakes simultaneously, starting 30 meters apart.
The v-t graph shows the truck starting at 40 m/s and coming to rest in 20 seconds, and the bus starting at 30 m/s and coming to rest in 30 seconds.

premise: Truck: initial speed 40 m/s; comes to rest in 20 s. Bus: initial speed 30 m/s; comes to rest in 30 s.
conclusion: Truck’s deceleration: aₜ = −40/20 = −2 m/s². Bus’s deceleration: a_b = −30/30 = −1 m/s².

premise: Truck’s deceleration: aₜ = −2 m/s². Bus’s deceleration: a_b = −1 m/s².
conclusion: Truck’s speed as a function of time: vₜ(t) = 40 − 2t (for 0 ≤ t ≤ 20 s). Bus’s speed as a function of time: v_b(t) = 30 − 1t (for 0 ≤ t ≤ 30 s).

premise: Truck’s speed: vₜ(t) = 40 − 2t. Bus’s speed: v_b(t) = 30 − 1t.
conclusion: Position of truck by integrating vₜ(t): xₜ(t) = 40t − t² (0 ≤ t ≤ 20). Position of bus by integrating v_b(t): x_b(t) = 30t − ½t² (0 ≤ t ≤ 30).

premise: Initial separation: 30 m. Position of truck: xₜ(t) = 40t − t². Position of bus: x_b(t) = 30t − ½t².
conclusion: Separation as a function of time: s(t) = 30 + xₜ(t) − x_b(t) = 30 + 10t − ½t².
Maximum separation occurs when ds/dt = 0: ds/dt = 10 − t = 0 ⇒ t = 10 s.

premise: Maximum separation occurs at t = 10 s.
